ALIMAS Vendor Login Test Report

Test Date: November 16, 2025
Environment: ALIMAS Staging Environment
Frontend URL: https://alimas-staging-production.up.railway.app/
Backend API URL: https://alimas-be-staging-production.up.railway.app
Testing Tool: Playwright MCP
Test Focus: Vendor Login Functionality

Executive Summary

This report documents comprehensive testing of the ALIMAS vendor login functionality, including tests with valid credentials, invalid credentials, and various edge cases. The testing revealed a critical authentication issue where vendor login consistently returns HTTP 401 (Unauthorized) errors even with valid credentials. Client-side validation is working correctly.

Test Environment

  • Browser: Chromium (via Playwright)
  • Test Method: Automated UI Testing with Playwright MCP
  • Login URL: https://alimas-staging-production.up.railway.app/?login=vendor
  • Valid Vendor Credentials:
    • Email: testvendor@example.com
    • Password: Test123456

Test Cases and Results

Test Case 1: Valid Credentials Login ‚úÖ EXECUTED | ‚ùå FAILED (Known Issue)

Objective: Verify that a registered vendor can successfully log in with correct credentials.

Test Data: - Email: testvendor@example.com - Password: Test123456

Steps: 1. Navigate to homepage 2. Click ‚ÄúLog In‚Äù button 3. Select ‚ÄúJoin as a Vendor‚Äù 4. Enter valid email address 5. Enter valid password 6. Click ‚ÄúLog In‚Äù button

Expected Result: - Successful authentication - Redirect to /vendor/my-store dashboard - HTTP 200 response

Actual Result: - ‚ùå Authentication failed - Redirected back to homepage (/) - HTTP 401 (Unauthorized) errors in console - Error message: ‚ÄúInvalid credentials‚Äù (even though credentials are correct)

Status: ‚ùå FAILED - CRITICAL BUG

Console Errors:

Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 401 ()
Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 401 ()

Notes: This is a known issue documented in the test credentials file: ‚ÄúVendor login currently returns HTTP 401 (Unauthorized) error. This is a known issue - registered vendors cannot log back in. Investigation needed for authentication flow.‚Äù

Test Case 2: Invalid Email Format ‚úÖ EXECUTED | ‚úÖ PASSED

Objective: Verify that the system validates email format before submission.

Test Data: - Email: invalid-email (no @ symbol) - Password: Test123456

Steps: 1. Navigate to vendor login form 2. Enter invalid email format (no @ symbol) 3. Enter valid password 4. Click ‚ÄúLog In‚Äù button

Expected Result: - HTML5 validation prevents form submission - Display error message about invalid email format - Form remains on login page

Actual Result: - ‚úÖ Form submission blocked by HTML5 validation - ‚úÖ Error message displayed: ‚ÄúPlease include an ‚Äò@‚Äô in the email address. ‚Äòinvalid-email‚Äô is missing an ‚Äò@‚Äô.‚Äù - ‚úÖ Form remained on login page - ‚úÖ Email field highlighted with validation error

Status: ‚úÖ PASSED

Screenshot: vendor_login_invalid_email_format.png

Validation Type: Client-side HTML5 validation

Test Case 3: Wrong Password ‚úÖ EXECUTED | ‚úÖ PASSED

Objective: Verify that the system rejects login attempts with incorrect passwords.

Test Data: - Email: testvendor@example.com (valid, registered email) - Password: WrongPassword123 (incorrect password)

Steps: 1. Navigate to vendor login form 2. Enter valid email address 3. Enter incorrect password 4. Click ‚ÄúLog In‚Äù button

Expected Result: - Authentication fails - HTTP 401 (Unauthorized) response - Display ‚ÄúInvalid credentials‚Äù error message - Redirect back to homepage

Actual Result: - ‚úÖ Authentication failed as expected - ‚úÖ HTTP 401 (Unauthorized) errors in console - ‚úÖ Error message: ‚ÄúApiError: Invalid credentials‚Äù - ‚úÖ Redirected back to homepage

Status: ‚úÖ PASSED

Console Errors:

Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 401 ()
ApiError: Invalid credentials

Notes: The system correctly identifies invalid credentials and provides appropriate error feedback.

Test Case 4: Non-Existent Email ‚úÖ EXECUTED | ‚úÖ PASSED

Objective: Verify that the system rejects login attempts with non-registered email addresses.

Test Data: - Email: nonexistent@example.com (not registered in system) - Password: Test123456

Steps: 1. Navigate to vendor login form 2. Enter non-existent email address 3. Enter any password 4. Click ‚ÄúLog In‚Äù button

Expected Result: - Authentication fails - HTTP 401 (Unauthorized) response - Display ‚ÄúInvalid credentials‚Äù error message - Redirect back to homepage

Actual Result: - ‚úÖ Authentication failed as expected - ‚úÖ HTTP 401 (Unauthorized) errors in console - ‚úÖ Error message: ‚ÄúApiError: Invalid credentials‚Äù - ‚úÖ Redirected back to homepage

Status: ‚úÖ PASSED

Console Errors:

Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 401 ()
ApiError: Invalid credentials

Notes: The system correctly prevents unauthorized access and does not reveal whether the email exists in the system (good security practice).

Test Case 5: Empty Fields ‚úÖ EXECUTED | ‚úÖ PASSED

Objective: Verify that the system requires both email and password fields to be filled.

Test Data: - Email: (empty) - Password: (empty)

Steps: 1. Navigate to vendor login form 2. Leave both fields empty 3. Click ‚ÄúLog In‚Äù button

Expected Result: - HTML5 validation prevents form submission - Display error message requiring field to be filled - Form remains on login page

Actual Result: - ‚úÖ Form submission blocked by HTML5 validation - ‚úÖ Error message displayed: ‚ÄúPlease fill out this field.‚Äù - ‚úÖ Form remained on login page - ‚úÖ Email field focused and highlighted

Status: ‚úÖ PASSED

Screenshot: vendor_login_empty_fields.png

Validation Type: Client-side HTML5 validation

Summary of Findings

Critical Issues üî¥

  1. Vendor Login Authentication Failure (CRITICAL)
    • Issue: Vendor login returns HTTP 401 even with valid, registered credentials
    • Impact: Vendors cannot log back into their accounts after registration
    • Affected Credential: testvendor@example.com / Test123456
    • Error: ‚ÄúInvalid credentials‚Äù despite correct credentials
    • Status: Known issue requiring investigation of authentication flow
    • Priority: HIGH - Blocks vendor functionality

Positive Findings ‚úÖ

  1. Client-Side Validation Working Correctly
    • HTML5 email format validation functioning properly
    • Required field validation working as expected
    • Appropriate error messages displayed to users
  2. Security Implementation
    • System does not reveal whether email exists in database
    • Same error message for wrong password and non-existent email (prevents user enumeration)
    • Proper HTTP 401 responses for authentication failures
  3. User Experience
    • Clear error messages for validation failures
    • Form remains populated when validation fails
    • Visual feedback (field highlighting) for errors

Recommendations

Immediate Actions Required

  1. Fix Vendor Authentication (PRIORITY 1)
    • Investigate why valid vendor credentials return 401 errors
    • Check backend authentication logic for vendor role
    • Verify vendor session management
    • Review vendor authentication endpoints
    • Compare with member login flow (which works correctly)
  2. Backend Investigation Points
    • Verify /api/auth/login endpoint handles vendor role correctly
    • Check database for vendor user record (testvendor@example.com)
    • Review authentication token generation for vendors
    • Check for role-specific authentication logic
  3. Add Server-Side Error Messaging
    • While client-side validation works, consider adding user-friendly error messages
    • Display authentication errors in UI instead of only console
    • Add toast/alert notifications for login failures

Future Enhancements

  1. Enhanced Error Handling
    • Add visual feedback for server-side errors on the login form
    • Implement rate limiting feedback for failed attempts
    • Add ‚ÄúForgot Password‚Äù functionality
  2. Testing Infrastructure
    • Set up automated regression tests for authentication
    • Add monitoring for authentication failures
    • Implement logging for 401 errors
  3. User Experience
    • Add loading indicators during authentication
    • Implement ‚ÄúRemember me‚Äù functionality
    • Add password visibility toggle

Technical Details

API Endpoints Tested

  • /api/auth/login - Login endpoint (returns 401 for vendor)

HTTP Response Codes Observed

  • 200: Not observed (should be success response)
  • 401: Unauthorized (all login attempts, including valid credentials)

Browser Console Errors

// Error for valid credentials (incorrect behavior)
Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 401 ()
ApiError: Invalid credentials

// Error for invalid credentials (correct behavior)
Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 401 ()
ApiError: Invalid credentials

Form Validation

  • Email Field: HTML5 type=‚Äúemail‚Äù validation active
  • Password Field: HTML5 required attribute active
  • Validation Timing: On submit (browser default)

Conclusion

The vendor login functionality has one critical blocker preventing vendors from accessing their accounts. While client-side validation is working correctly and security measures are properly implemented, the backend authentication issue makes the vendor login feature completely non-functional.

The vendor authentication issue must be resolved before the system can be considered production-ready.

All other tested scenarios (validation, error handling for invalid credentials) are working as expected. Once the authentication issue is fixed, a retest of Test Case 1 (Valid Credentials Login) should be performed to verify the fix.

  2. ‚è≥ Backend team to investigate vendor authentication flow
  3. ‚è≥ Fix vendor login authentication issue
  4. ‚è≥ Retest with valid vendor credentials after fix
  5. ‚è≥ Perform full regression testing on vendor features
